definition:
reliance on the truth or reality of something                                      
             
             gave credit to everything he said
the balance in a person's favor in an account
an amount or sum placed at a person's disposal by a bank

the provision of money, goods, or services with the expectation of future payment                                      
             
             long-term credit
an entry on the right-hand side of an account constituting an addition to a revenue, net worth, or liability account
a deduction from an expense or asset account
any one of or the sum of the items entered on the right-hand side of an account
a deduction from an amount otherwise due
influence or power derived from enjoying the confidence of another or others
good name : esteem
credibility

a source of honor                                      
             
             a credit to the school

something that gains or adds to reputation or esteem : honor                                      
             
             He took no credit for his kindly act.

recognition, acknowledgment                                      
             
             quite willing to accept undeserved credit

recognition by name of a person contributing to a performance (such as a film or telecast)                                      
             
             the opening credits
recognition by a school or college that a student has fulfilled a requirement leading to a degree

credit hour                                      
             
             earned 15 credits last semester

to trust in the truth of : believe                                      
             
             find his story hard to credit
to supply goods on credit to
to bring credit or honor upon
to enter upon the credit side of an account

to place an amount to the credit of                                      
             
             credit his account with ten dollars

to consider usually favorably as the source, agent, or performer of an action or the possessor of a trait                                      
             
             credits him with an excellent sense of humor

to attribute to some person                                      
             
             They credit the invention to him.
money that a bank or business will allow a person to use and then pay back in the future
a record of how well you have paid your bills in the past
an amount of money that is added to an account
to add (an amount of money) to a total
to add money to (an account)
to give honor or recognition to (someone or something) for doing something or for making something happen

recognition or honor received for some quality or work                                      
             
             A doctor was given credit for the discovery.
the balance in an account in a person's favor
money or goods or services allowed to a person by a bank or business with the expectation of payment later
good reputation especially for honesty : high standing

a source of honor or pride                                      
             
             You are a credit to your school.

a unit of schoolwork                                      
             
             I took two credits in Spanish.

belief or trust in the truth of something                                      
             
             These rumors deserve no credit.

to give recognition or honor to for something                                      
             
             The team credited their coach for the championship.

to place something in a person's favor on (a business account)                                      
             
             We will credit your account with ten dollars.

believe sense 2                                      
             
             Don't credit a statement from a stranger.
recognition  — see also full faith and credit
the balance in an account which may be drawn upon and repaid later  — compare loan

the use of resources (as money) in the present obtained by the debtor's promise to repay the creditor in the future usually with interest as compensation to the creditor and often secured by a pledge of property or the right to attach the debtor's income in case of a failure to repay  — see also consumer credit  — compare debt

financial reputation                                      
             
             to borrow money on the credit of the United States
letter of credit
a reduction of an amount otherwise due
to trust in the truth of
in: gave credit to everything he said
Give no credit to idle rumors.
long-term credit
They exhausted their credit.
a credit to the school
He took no credit for his kindly act.
quite willing to accept undeserved credit
the opening credits
earned 15 credits last semester
find his story hard to credit
credit his account with ten dollars
credits him with an excellent sense of humor
They credit the invention to him.
my belief that I had caught all the errors
an unshakable faith in God
a theory now given credence by scientists
gave full credit to the statement of a reputable witness
used her influence to get the bill passed
his opinions lacked authority
the prestige of the newspaper
their wishes obviously carried much weight
his credit with the press
forged paintings formerly ascribed to masters
attributed to Rembrandt but possibly done by an associate
assigned the bones to the Cretaceous period
tried to impute sinister motives to my actions
credited his teammates for his success
banks that extend credit to the public

You've got to give her credit; she knows what she's doing.

She got extra credit for her report.
You are a credit to your school.
I took two credits in Spanish.
These rumors deserve no credit.

to borrow money on the credit of the United States
a credit for child-care expenses

definition: an arrangement to receive goods from a shop or money from a bank and pay for it later
praise for something you have done or achieved
an amount of money that you add to an account. An amount of money that you take out of an account is a debit
an amount of money that you have a right to, for example money that you can use to pay part of your tax bill
a part of a college or university course that you have completed successfully
a film, television programme, play etc that a particular person has worked on
a list of the people involved in making a film or television programme that is shown at the end or beginning of it
in: on credit: I don’t like buying things on credit.
give/offer credit: Some suppliers will not give credit to their customers.
interest-free credit: You can get interest-free credit on all our products.
credit for: You deserve credit for making him change his mind.
take the credit: He always takes the credit for my ideas.
All credits, debits, and charges will show on your bank statement.
the credit column of a balance sheet
These tax credits are designed to help offset the costs of child-care.
The government plans to introduce export credits.
This course counts as one credit towards your degree.
a director whose television credits include NYPD Blue
the closing/end/opening credits: The song plays over the opening credits.
be a credit to someone
credit where credit’s due
give someone credit for something
in credit
on the credit side
to someone’s credit

definition: praise, approval, or honour:
to do something that makes a person, group, or organization feel proud or receive praise:
to cause someone who has been or is responsible for you to receive praise by your good behaviour or successful actions:
used to show that you think a person deserves a lot of praise for something that they have done:
a method of paying for goods or services at a later time, usually paying interest as well as the original money:
money in your bank account:
a unit that represents a successfully finished part of an educational course:
a list of people who helped to make a film or a television or radio programme, that is shown or announced at the beginning or the end of it
to pay money into a bank account:
to believe something that seems unlikely to be true:
a method of buying goods or services that allows you to pay for them in the future:
praise or approval, esp. to recognize achievement:
an amount of money available to you because you paid for something earlier, or a record of this money:
A credit is also an amount of money you do not have to pay:
a unit of measurement of the value contributed by an educational course to a college degree:
to believe or trust something that may not be true:
a method of paying for goods or services at a later time, usually paying interest as well as the original amount:
the money lent by financial organizations to companies, governments, people, etc.:
the amount of risk when lending money to a particular person or organization, based on how likely they are to pay it back:
a payment of money into a bank account:
if a person or their bank account is in credit, there is money in the account:
an amount recorded on the right side of a company's financial accounts, which shows a decrease in assets or an increase in debt:
an amount by which someone is allowed to reduce the amount of tax they pay, because they have spent money on a particular thing:
an amount of money that you have available to spend with a store or business, for example, because you returned a product or paid too much for it:
praise for doing something good:
to show that money has been added to something such as an account:
to record an amount on the right side of a company's financial accounts to show a decrease in assets or an increase in debt:

Also known as: 
-Creds (k-reds)
-Tokens (tOe-KeNs)

1. Currency usually used in arcades.  For each money value you place into an arcade machine, you get a credit.  

Usually 1-5 credits are needed to play a game and can accept (depending on the arcade): Tokens, Nickels, Quarters, Swipe Cards, and on some occasions, free.

2. Coins for arcades;a.k.a. tokens.
